Research article Understanding the role of metal oxide support in ruthenium-based catalysts for ammonia synthesis via interpretable machine learning Rasika Jayarathna Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Investigation Conceptualization Rahat Javaid Writing – review & editing Investigation Jochen Lauterbach Writing – review & editing Supervision Funding acquisition Conceptualization ⁎ Department of Chemical Engineering, University of South Carolina, 541 Main St., Columbia, SC 29208, USA Department of Chemical Engineering University of South Carolina 541 Main St. Columbia SC 29208 USA Department of Chemical Engineering, University of South Carolina, 541 Main St., Columbia, SC 29208, USA ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract The results suggest that in addition to basicity, a certain acidity of metal oxide support and the ability to form metal hydrides could be critical to the NH3 synthesis reaction. The role of metal oxide supports is complex in heterogeneous catalysis due to acidity, basicity, and surface defects. Interpretable machine learning models trained on experimental data could lead to new insights about these complexities, which are rarely verified through detailed catalyst characterization. This study explores the role of metal oxide supports for the Ru-based ammonia synthesis catalysts using Shapley additive explanations (SHAP). The support metal nitride formation energy and the support metal hydride formation energy were identified as critical descriptors that could describe the ammonia synthesis activity. These descriptors and the related catalyst characterization by Ammonia-Temperature Programmed Desorption and Hydrogen-Temperature Programmed Desorption suggest new processes that could govern the ammonia synthesis reaction. It is suggested that in addition to basicity, the metal oxide support should possess a certain acidity to alleviate ammonia inhibition and form metal hydrides to alleviate hydrogen inhibition. Keywords Ammonia synthesis Interpretable machine learning Metal oxide Heterogeneous catalysis Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Metal oxide supports play a major role in heterogeneous catalysis. In addition to acting as a carrier to disperse and stabilize the active components as nanosized sites, they play a critical role by providing functionality that enhances the reaction [1]. These functionalities depend on the complex nature of metal oxide surfaces, which have diverse acidic sites, basic sites, and defects. Hence, the development of descriptors for metal oxides to describe their behavior is more challenging compared to metals [2]. While theory-guided descriptors have developed scaling relationships and reactivity descriptors for metal oxides, those are mostly limited to bulk metal oxide reactivity and supported metal oxides where experimental complexities of bulk metal oxides are largely disregarded, which play a significant role in metal oxide supports [2,3]. For instance, the same metal oxide support could have significantly different surface structures when various types of synthesis methods are used, leading to varying catalytic performances [4–6]. These complexities are further increased due to aspects such as metal-support interactions and hydrogen spillover, which could govern the catalyst performance [7,8]. Understanding these aspects is critical for the further development of metal oxide-supported catalysts. Ruthenium (Ru) nanoparticles supported on metal oxide are a class of catalysts where the support plays a significant role in catalyst activity [9]. These catalysts are gaining widespread attraction as a potential catalyst for thermochemical ammonia (NH3) synthesis under mild conditions (<5 MPa, <450 °C) due to high activity and stability where NH3 is to be used as a carrier for hydrogen (H2) generated from excess renewable electricity [10,11]. Electrochemical, photochemical, and plasma-assisted processes for NH3 synthesis under milder conditions are investigated as alternatives to the thermochemical process [12]. However, these processes are still not efficient enough for commercialization, and a more technologically mature thermochemical approach is suitable for diverse applications, given the urgency to meet the decarbonization goals set by the Paris Agreement [13]. The main drawback of metal oxide-supported Ru catalysts has been hydrogen inhibition/poisoning, where the higher activities are not achieved at higher pressures as expected by reaction thermodynamics [10]. Kinetic equations illustrate this behavior as having a negative reaction order to the partial pressure of hydrogen [10]. This phenomenon is mainly attributed to the active site blocking by activated hydrogen atoms and the subsequent restricted access for nitrogen to be activated for NH3 synthesis [14]. In addition to hydrogen poisoning, supported Ru catalysts also suffer from NH3 poisoning as well, as evidenced by the negative reaction order to the partial pressure of NH3 [9]. Metal oxide supports such as MgO suffer from this issue and exhibit lower activity [15]. Still, lanthanide metal oxide supports such as La2O3, CeO2, and Pr2O3 retard hydrogen poisoning and are reported as the best binary metal oxide supports for Ru nanoparticles [9,15,16]. The high density of basic sites measured using CO2 temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) has been mostly attributed to the higher catalytic activities observed at 1–3 MPa [9]. However, a strong correlation between the density of basic sites and turnover frequency (TOF) was not observed over a wide range of metal oxide supports since supported Ru catalysts with different metal oxide supports have similar TOFs for different densities of basic sites [9]. The strength of basic sites, which is defined as the temperature of the CO2 desorption peak observed below 500 °C, also does not correlate with the activity [17]. The high density of basic sites or strong basic sites would transfer the electron density from the support surface to the Ru nanoparticles to accelerate the rate-determining step [18]. However, a lack of strong correlation with the basicity of the metal oxide support over a wide range suggests that other factors might be at play in affecting the activity of these catalysts. Further increases in activity have been achieved by ternary metal oxide supports with lanthanide metals such as La2Ce2O7 (La0.5Ce0.5O1.75) and La2Pr2O7 (La0.5Pr0.5O1.75) [19–21]. Catalysts based on these supports suppress hydrogen poisoning and achieve higher activities than their parent lanthanide oxides. The La2Ce2O7 and La2Pr2O7 required high-temperature reduction at 650 °C to induce strong metal support interaction and filtration of impurities in N2 and H2, such as O2 and H2O from ppm to ppt levels to achieve and stabilize high activities, which are reported to be the highest activities to date for unpromoted and supported Ru catalysts [19,20]. However, it has been shown that La2Ce2O7 still outperforms La2O3 and CeO2 under widely utilized 500 °C reduction and without specific filtration for the reactants [4,22]. These high activities of La2Ce2O7 were attributed to the dispersion of Ru [22] and the desorption behavior of hydrogen [4], which were primarily rationalized based on characterizing the parent oxides or a few different oxides. The moderate activities obtained by BaCeO3, BaZrO3, and BaTiO3 perovskite oxide supports were attributed to strong basicity compared to some other binary metal oxides [21,23,24]. Since the effect of the metal oxide support was not clear over a large range of metal oxides or reasoned based on a smaller number of metal oxides, analysis of a large number of metal oxides is essential to identify better descriptors and their relationships with NH3 synthesis activity on Ru supported on metal oxides. Machine learning (ML) models trained on experimental data are capable of building intricate relationships between descriptors and catalyst performance. Post-hoc analysis techniques are then used to make these 'black-box' models interpretable, where relevant information about relationships between descriptors and catalyst performance is extracted [25,26]. These types of models have been largely limited to descriptors such as reaction conditions, material compositions, and generic elemental properties, which do not give much physical insight into the catalytic process [27–29]. Even when meaningful relationships are extracted from these models, they are rarely verified for their physical existence through catalyst characterization [30]. Interpretable ML models combined with catalyst characterization would increase the trust in ML models, leading to scientific knowledge generation. Shapley additive explanations (SHAP) [31] facilitate the interpretability of the ML models so that these relationships can be extracted. Unlike global descriptor importance scores (a.k.a. feature importance) [32], where the effect of the descriptors is estimated based on average trends by considering the dataset as a whole (i.e., global explanations), SHAP values estimate the effect of each descriptor for every data point in the dataset (i.e., local explanations) [25]. The average of these SHAP values for each descriptor generates global explanations. Furthermore, SHAP values estimate whether the effects are positive or negative in contrast to global descriptor importance scores, where only the effect is estimated. Hence, SHAP values are more effective in identifying the impact of descriptors on catalyst performance. Here in, we focus on understanding the effect of metal oxide support on NH3 synthesis activity by interpreting an ML model trained on literature data. The descriptors for the model would be generated based on theories and hypotheses that have not been widely explored in the literature. The relationships given by the SHAP values are tested for physical existence with the aid of catalyst characterization. It is hoped that this verification will allow the formation of new knowledge and hypotheses for the NH3 synthesis reaction. The whole process is illustrated in Fig. 1 . 2 Methods 2.1 Data collection The experimental data for developing the machine learning model to predict the NH3 synthesis activity were mined from the literature. This dataset is a subset of the data the authors collected in a previous study [33]. Since the metal oxide support effect is investigated, the data was selected so that catalysts have no promoters. Li et al. demonstrated that Ru/La0.5Ce0.5O1.75 catalysts, where the support was synthesized using co-precipitation and hydrothermal methods, have a significant difference in activities [4]. This behavior was attributed to the high number of defect sites (characterized by the ultraviolet–visible spectroscopy) for the metal oxide prepared by the co-precipitation method compared to the one prepared by the hydrothermal method, which facilitates efficient hydrogen migration. Hence, supports synthesized using only co-precipitation were selected to eliminate the effect of the support synthesis method on the NH3 synthesis activity. The distribution of the 193 data points in the dataset, according to the type of oxide support in the catalyst, is shown in Fig. 2 . This dataset contains binary metal oxides (e.g., MgO, CeO2, Pr2O3) and ternary metal oxides (e.g., BaCeO3, La2Ce2O7, La2Pr2O7), which are stoichiometric. All of these oxides have basic sites and acid sites except MgO, making them amphoteric [34–36]. The vast majority of data points are attributed to the widely investigated oxides of La2Ce2O7, BaCeO3, Pr2O3, CeO2, and MgO. The remaining supports mostly include other rare earth oxide supports such as Sm2O3, La2O3, Nd2O3, Er2O3, and Ho2O3 and mixed oxide supports such as La2Pr2O7 and BaZrO3. 2.2 Descriptor engineering, selection, and model development Extra descriptors were generated in addition to the reaction conditions (temperature, pressure, equilibrium constant, space velocity, etc.), physical parameters of the catalyst (Ru mol%, Ru to support molar ratio, support surface area), and catalyst pretreatment conditions (H2 % in the pretreatment gas, pretreatment temperature) of the NH3 synthesis catalysts. Molar composition-based descriptors for the metal oxides were generated by combining the elemental properties (i.e., atomic radius, first ionization energy, etc.) of the elements in the metal oxide with the mols of elements in the oxide. The same descriptors were generated only regarding metals as the oxide elements to represent the effect of the metals. Properties of the metal oxides extracted from the materials project website were also considered as descriptors. Finally, descriptors were generated based on the domain knowledge of the oxide supports for NH3 synthesis catalysts. Since the electronic structure of the support surface, i.e., basicity plays a significant role in the activity of the catalysts, adescriptor is necessary to represent this effect. The dataset primarily includes lanthanide oxide supports, which are amphoteric with Lewis basic and acidic sites [34–36]. High surface acidity of the supports such as γ-Al2O3 and Nb2O5 is generally considered detrimental to the NH3 synthesis reaction due to the absence of sufficient electronic density to drive the reaction [37,38]. Horiuchi et al. attributed the high surface acidity of the TiO2 to the low activity of the Ru/TiO2 and the increase of the activity of Ru/CaTiO3, Ru/SrTiO3, and Ru/BaTiO3 compared to Ru/TiO2 to the reducing the acidity of TiO2 [39]. BaTiO3 had the weakest interaction with NH3 and the highest activity among the other supports; hence, it was implied that synthesized NH3 would easily desorb due to the lower acidity, which increased NH3 synthesis activity. However, this effect is not largely explored in the context of Ru-based NH3 synthesis catalysts for an extensive range of supports in the literature. As a descriptor of the surface acidity of the oxide support, the interaction between the NH3 molecule and the surface acid site can be considered, which can be characterized by NH3-Temperature Programmed Desorption (TPD) experiments. Here, the one lone pair of the NH3 molecule interacts with the metal cations on the support surface, which are regarded as acid sites, forming a metal-nitrogen bond [40]. The formation energies of metal nitrides can approximate the strength of the metal-nitrogen bond since higher negative formation energies correspond to higher bond energies. This reasoning can be further justified since NH3 starts reacting with certain metal oxides, such as tungsten oxide (WO3), under the NH3 atmosphere at temperatures around 450 °C and completely transforms the oxide to tungsten nitride (WN) at 700 °C [41]. Hence, the formation energy of the most thermodynamically stable metal nitride for the support metal extracted from the materials project website [42] can be used as a descriptor of this phenomenon for each metal oxide. Due to the formation of metal nitrides with different metal-to-nitrogen molar ratios, the formation energy per nitrogen mols and metal mols were used as initial descriptors to isolate the metal-nitrogen bond effect. The mean, maximum, and minimum of the formation energies of individual metals were used as descriptors to represent this effect for mixed metal oxides. It should be noted that these extracted formation energies had been calculated based on density functional theory (DFT). Due to the higher agreement with experimental formation energies, the formation energies calculated utilizing a mixed approach with generalized gradient approximation (GGA) and restored-regularized Strongly Constrained and Appropriately Normed (r2SCAN) meta-GGA functional (GGA/GGA + U/r2SCAN) were selected from the materials project database as seen in Table S1 [43]. Here, thermodynamic stability is quantified with the 'energy above hull' parameter, and its value equals 0 for a thermodynamically stable compound. Metastable compounds were considered to have an energy above the hull value between 0 and 0.2, and unstable compounds were considered to have a value of over 0.2. If a stable compound was not found in the database, the most stable compound with the lowest formation energy (eV/atom) was chosen, considering all the meta-stable compounds. The mixed approach of GGA/GGA + U/r2SCAN, employed here for selecting the most stable compound, was devised by Kingsbury et al. [43] to minimize the risk of distortion in phase diagrams due to the mixing of two approaches by GGA and r2SCAN, which is in agreement with experimental formation energies. It was assumed that metal nitrides are formed under reaction conditions or the formation energy would represent the interaction between the NH3 molecules and the metal oxide surface. Similarly, a descriptor is necessary to describe the effect of H2 on the metal oxide support surface. Once the H2 is dissociated on the facets of the Ru nanoparticle, atomic hydrogen migrates to the oxide surface for reducible oxide supports such as CeO2 and TiO2, known as hydrogen spillover [6,44]. Recent studies have shown that hydrogen migration from Ru to the supports occurs in supported Ru catalysts with non-reducible oxides Ru/La2O3 and Ru/Sm2O3 [45,46]. Even if these oxides are regarded as non-reducible since metal cations of the oxides are not reduced, atomic hydrogen can spill from Ru to the support and create an oxygen vacancy near Ru nanoparticles, as evidenced by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) [45]. Heterolytic dissociation of H2 occurs in the presence of oxygen vacancies for reducible oxides such as CeO2 [47,48] and non-reducible oxides such as Sm2O3 [45] as shown by DFT calculations and spectroscopic studies. Consequently, metal hydrides and hydroxyl groups are formed on the metal oxide surface near Ru nanoparticles. Increasing the reduction/pretreatment time and the temperature increases the amount of metal hydrides formed, which increases the electronic density of Ru and facilitates the reaction by directly participating as a form of hydrogen species [45,46]. However, similar to the acidity of metal oxides, this phenomenon has not been well studied for an extensive range of metal oxides. The formation energies of the most thermodynamically stable metal hydrides for the support metal were extracted from the materials project website [42] (Table S2) and used as descriptors for each oxide. Due to the formation of metal hydrides with different metal-to-hydrogen molar ratios, the formation energy per hydrogen mols and metal mols were used as initial descriptors to isolate the metal-hydrogen bond effect. The mean, maximum, and minimum of the formation energies of individual metals were used for mixed oxides. A similar approach was also applied to the formation energies of metal hydroxides (Table S3). The extraction process of formation energies for these compounds was similar to metal nitrides. In addition, the most thermodynamically stable alloy formation energy of Ru and support metal was used as a descriptor for the strong metal support interaction, which was developed in a previous study [49]. The extra trees regressor (ETR) model was selected due to its high accuracy for small datasets in this context, which has been previously demonstrated [33]. The descriptors relevant to the dataset were chosen using the step-forward descriptor selection method implemented in the Python package mlxtend (version 0.22.0) [50]. At first, every descriptor is individually evaluated for the ML model, and one with the least mean squared error is selected. Next, this selected descriptor and one of the remaining descriptors are combined, which is re-evaluated for the least mean squared error, and the next best descriptor is selected. Likewise, descriptors are added subsequently until a subset of the descriptors is selected with the best cross-validation performance. 2.3 Model interpretation using SHAP SHAP is based on the cooperative game theory, and this method can be explained by an example of a group of players that are in a game to win a monetary prize. When this team wins the game, the monetary prize has to be fairly distributed among players according to each player's contribution. This contribution is estimated by calculating the average contribution of a player to the prize using the Shapley values, introduced in 1951 by Lord Shapley [51]. Here, the player's contribution for each subset of the team is calculated, and the contributions are averaged, which is the marginal contribution of each player to the team. The SHAP method applies a modified version of this example, where descriptors become players, the game becomes the ML model, and the prize becomes the predicted value. Hence, SHAP can estimate the average contribution of each descriptor value (Shapley value of each descriptor value) to the predicted target value for each data point in the ML model. Shapley values are calculated using Eq. (1). Here, ϕi is the Shapley value of a datapoint for the descriptor i, with descriptor vector x and ML model f and z representing all possible subsets of x. fx(z)-fx(z\i) is the marginal contribution of the descriptor i, estimated by taking the difference of the predicted target value with (fx(z)) and without the descriptor (fx(z\i)). Each marginal contribution is weighted by the total number of possible permutations of descriptor subsets with a total number of descriptors M. Due to the computationally intractable nature of computing Shapley values using Eq. (1), approximation methods such as Kernel SHAP are used to estimate the Shapley values [31]. (1) ϕ i f , x = ∑ z ⊂ x z ! M - z - 1 ! M ! f x z - f x z \ i Properties of SHAP values include local accuracy, missingness, and consistency. Local accuracy entails the summation of Shapley values of each descriptor for a single data point and the average of all the target values, Ex(f(x)), being equal to the predicted target value f(x) of the data point (Eq. (2) [52]. Missingness means a missing descriptor has a contribution or Shapley value (ϕi) of 0. Consistency is shown for Shapley values when the model is changed. Shapley value is increased when the marginal contribution of the descriptor is increased. Furthermore, if the marginal contribution of the descriptor is not changed, then the Shapley value of that descriptor is also not changed. (2) f x = E x f x + ∑ i = 1 M ϕ i Since the original Kernel SHAP approach is based on descriptors that are independent (uncorrelated), it may lead to misleading interpretations [53]. Hence, a modified Kernel SHAP method to handle dependent (correlated) descriptors based on the empirical conditional distributions of descriptors developed by Aas et al. [53] and implemented in the Python package corr-shap (version 0.0.2) [54] is used to estimate SHAP values. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Model results After the step-forward descriptor selection, where 29 descriptors were selected out of 363 descriptors (Table S4), the ML model was evaluated for the total dataset using leave-one-group-out cross-validation,where data related to each support is considered a group. Here, each group is considered as the test dataset, and the remaining data becomes the training dataset. The parity plot for all groups (R2 = 0.79, RMSE = 9.04 for the entire dataset) with predicted versus measured NH3 synthesis rate values is seen in Fig. 3 (a). These results demonstrate that the model has failed to predict the activity of Pr2O3-supported catalysts, while the rest of the supported catalysts are predicted close to the parity line. The Pr2O3 support appears to be a major outlier. It has been experimentally demonstrated that the morphology of Ru on Pr2O3 is an outlier compared to all the other metal oxides in the dataset since Ru exists as a nano-layer on Pr2O3 instead of the conventional nanoparticle morphology [16]. The nano-layer of Ru was claimed to be formed by the interaction of the ruthenium carbonyl precursor (Ru3(CO)12) with the as-synthesized form of praseodymium oxide (PrOx) after the impregnation and calcination process [16]. In addition, the nature of the bulk structure of the PrOx is significantly non-uniform compared to other metal oxides. X-ray diffractograms of PrOx have assigned the bulk structure to PrO2, Pr6O11, and PrO1.83 oxides [55,56]. However, under the H2 atmosphere, in-situ X-ray diffractograms have revealed only Pr2O3 [16]. Due to this complex behavior of PrOx, the data related to Pr2O3 was removed from the data set for ML. The data related to the La2Pr2O7 support were retained since the morphology of Ru is in the form of nanoparticles [20]. The updated parity plot of the model is shown in Fig. 3(b). The model evaluation accuracy increased significantly with R2 = 0.90 and RMSE = 4.90 for the entire dataset, which shows the importance of removing outliers from the dataset. Hence, this updated dataset without Pr2O3 would be used for the model interpretation. Consequently, this model is limited to catalysts where Ru has the morphology of nanoparticles supported on metal oxides with basic sites and a uniform crystal structure, which does not apply to other types of morphologies of Ru and metal oxides with non-uniform crystal structures or without basic sites. 50 descriptors were selected out of 363 descriptors using the step-forward descriptor selection for the updated dataset, which are shown in Table S7, and hyperparameters were tuned (Table S6). As expected, the reaction conditions, catalyst pretreatment parameters, and Ru mol% that impact the NH3 synthesis rates have been selected as descriptors. Interestingly, the reaction temperature has not been chosen as a descriptor since it is incorporated in the selected descriptor, the equilibrium constant of the NH3 synthesis reaction. Electronic properties of the support and support metal, such as electron affinity, number of valence electrons, and ionization energy, have been selected by the descriptor selection method, which agrees with the current knowledge of the high NH3 synthesis rates that result from the electronic promotion from the support, i.e., high basicity [9,21,23]. The newly defined descriptors for hydride and nitride formation energies were also selected, which implies that these descriptors might be significant. Descriptors related to the metal hydroxide formation energies have not been selected, which could hint at their insignificance. Other descriptors not selected include the support surface area. This behavior can be explained by the change in the surface area of the Ru-impregnated support after the reduction or pretreatment of the catalyst. For instance, the surface area of the as-synthesized catalyst of Ru/La2Pr2O7 was 40 m2g−1 [20]. The reduction/pretreatment temperatures of 500 °C to 650 and 700 °C changed the surface areas of the catalysts to 34, 30, and 23 m2g−1, respectively [20]. The same behavior was observed for Ru/La2Ce2O7, where the catalyst surface area was 47, 42, and 21 m2g−1 for reduction/pretreatment temperatures 500, 650, and 700 °C, respectively [19]. Due to the lack of data on catalyst surface area in the literature, the same support surface area was used as a descriptor for the dataset for different pretreatment temperatures. Consequently, the support surface area was not selected as a descriptor since the pretreatment temperature could represent these changes. 3.2 Model interpretation. The correlation matrix (Fig. S1) illustrates that some descriptors are highly correlated, which justifies the use of the modified Kernel SHAP method for estimating SHAP values. Highly correlated descriptors were not removed since these descriptors were selected using the step-forward feature selection method to improve the model accuracy while ensuring no overfitting. Fig. 4 shows the mean SHAP absolute values for each descriptor of the ML model and the distribution of these values accordingto the descriptor's category. The mean absolute SHAP values represent the global effect of each descriptor, and it is apparent that descriptors related to support alone have a more significant impact than the effects from other aspects of the catalyst. To estimate the local effect of descriptors, the SHAP value was plotted for every data point for each descriptor so that the contribution of each descriptor to the NH3 synthesis rate is estimated for every data point (Fig. S2-S7). A positive SHAP value of a descriptor for a particular data point means that the contribution of the descriptor value of that data point positively impacts the NH3 synthesis rate and vice versa [57]. Plotting the SHAP value of a specific descriptor versus the value of the descriptor for all data points assists in visualizing the impact of that descriptor on the NH3 synthesis rate at a broader range. Out of all the plots for the SHAP value of descriptors, two of the descriptors generated based on domain knowledge appear to have a volcano-type relationship with their respective descriptor values. These two descriptors are the support metal nitride formation energy per metal mol mean and the support metal hydride formation energy per H mol minimum (Fig. 5 ). Similar volcano-type relationships have been reported for ML models trained on experimental heterogeneous catalysis data [58,59]. Ding et al. identified a similar relationship for the SHAP value of the content of pyridinic species versus the content of pyridinic species for an ML model trained to predict the half-wave potential that was used as the indicator of catalytic activity for oxygen reduction reaction [59]. A study by Suvarna et al. revealed a volcano-type relationship between the space–time yield of higher alcohol synthesis using syngas versus a novel descriptor (based on the combination of two elemental properties) developed for promoters of rhodium-based catalysts applied for the reaction [58]. Volcano plots are related to core concepts in heterogeneous catalysis. The Sabatier principle has led to the development of qualitative volcano-type relationships between the catalyst activity and the bond strength between an adsorbate and an active site, where an optimal bond strength is required for optimal activity [60]. A strong bond strength limits the desorption of the product molecule, and a weaker bond strength limits the activation of the reactant [61]. Based on this principle, quantitative volcano plots have been produced for NH3 synthesis rates of K-promoted transition metal catalysts versus the DFT-calculated nitrogen adsorption energy, revealing Ru as the most active metal [62]. Similarly, an optimal support metal nitride formation energy appears to correspond to the optimal NH3 synthesis rate in the dataset, as seen in Fig. 5(a). Here, it should be noted that the mean formation energies are considered for ternary metal oxides as the mean formation energy was selected during the descriptor selection. A plot of some of the NH3 synthesis rate data of metal oxide-supported 5 wt% Ru catalysts under the same reaction condition used to train the ML model illustrate the same behavior (Fig. 6 (a)). As the absolute value of the support metal nitride formation energy increases, the metal-nitrogen bond strength of the metal nitride also increases. If the bond strength between the nitrogen atom in the NH3 molecule and the support metal cation in the acid site is represented by the metal-nitrogen bond strength in the metal nitride, then the strength of the acid sites on the metal oxide surface should be increased as the absolute value of the metal nitride formation energy is increased. 3.3 Experimental validation NH3-TPD of metal oxide supports characterizes the strength of the acid sites on the metal oxide surfaces. The NH3-TPD profiles of selected binary metal oxides, which increase the metal nitride formation energy per metal mol from top to bottom, are shown in Fig. 7 . As seen on the right-hand side of the plot in Fig. 6(a), MgO did not adsorb any measurable amounts of NH3 as expected since it is a predominantly basic oxide. However, Yb2O3, with a lower nitride formation energy (absolute value), has predominantly weak acid sites and desorbs NH3 up to 500 °C. As the nitride formation energy increases for La2O3, CeO2, and Sm2O3, NH3 is desorbing at temperatures up to 600 and 700 °C. Metal oxides on the left-hand side of the volcano with the highest metal nitride formation energy, such as Ho2O3 and Er2O3, have the strongest acid sites than all the other metal oxides in the plot, as evidenced by the higher fraction of NH3 desorbed at temperatures up to 800 °C. Hence, it appears that the metal nitride formation energy per metal mol has the potential to be a representative descriptor for the strength of acid sites on metal oxide surfaces. The experimental NH3 synthesis rates of these experimentally synthesized metal oxide-supported Ru catalysts (See supplementary information for catalyst synthesis and testing) differ from those used to train from the literature under the same reaction condition, as seen in Fig. 8 (a). This discrepancy could be attributed to the surface area of the metal oxide supports. The BET surface area of the experimentally synthesized metal oxide supports was 14–18 m2g−1, whereas it was 3–4 m2g−1 for the metal oxide supports in the literature [9], which may have caused this difference in activity. However, the volcano-type relationship is still apparent from the data. Catalysts on the two sides of the volcano with the supports MgO, Yb2O3, Ho2O3, and Er2O3 have synthesis rates that are significantly lower than the supports with CeO2, La2O3, and Sm2O3. This correlation with the NH3 synthesis rate and the support metal nitride formation energy implies that the strength of acid sites on the metal oxide surface might significantly impact the NH3 synthesis rate. One possible scenario is that the acid site strength impacts the electronic structure of the oxide surface, which differentiates the basicity of the metal oxides. Another scenario would be a possible migration of NH3 from the Ru nanoparticle to the metal oxide surface. The migrated NH3 could be adsorbed on the acid sites. If the strength of the acid sites is too low, NH3 might not migrate to the support, resulting in a higher degree of NH3 inhibition on Ru, causing lower synthesis rates such as MgO. On the other hand, if the strength of the acid sites is too high, the migrated NH3 would remain strongly adsorbed on the oxide surface, limiting the further migration of NH3 and causing a higher degree of NH3 inhibition. The support that contains the acid site with optimal strength would facilitate the efficient migration of NH3 from active sites to the acid sites of the support and the desorption of NH3 from the support surface. Consequently, it would result in an optimal NH3 synthesis rate. The other volcano-type relationship with the support metal hydride formation energy compared with the 5 wt%. Ru catalysts under the same reaction condition used to train the ML model demonstrate the same behavior (Fig. 6(b)). The volcano-type relationship is not as strong compared to the one with the previous descriptor, as there are multiple supports (La2O3, Nd2O3, Gd2O3) with a similar descriptor value but with a wide range of activity. However, this relationship is worth exploring since metal hydrides on the support surface affect the activity mentioned above by previous studies [45,46]. These studies have shown that metal hydrides are formed on the support metal under the reaction conditions (1–3 MPa, 400–600 °C) for Sm2O3 and La2O3 but not for MgO. The experiments to verify the existence of surface hydrides were done for Ru catalysts synthesized by the deposition–precipitation method and only for MgO, Sm2O3, and La2O3 [45,46]. However, since the catalysts in the dataset are synthesized using the wetness impregnation method, these experiments should be performed for those catalysts with more metal oxides. This experiment flows a 1 %O2 in N2 flow under pressure to a reduced catalyst where the H2 has been flushed out of the system by Ar (See Supplementary information). Oxygen replaces the hydrogen of the metal hydrides on the oxide surface, and asmall amount of NH3 is liberated from the process. This amount is detected by bubbling the effluent through a 0.001 M sulfuric acid solution and measuring the reduction in conductivity. As seen in Fig. 9 , only lanthanide oxide-supported catalysts cause the conductivity reduction, indicating that lanthanide oxide-supported form metal hydrides, whereas Ru/MgO does not. This experimental information matches the data in Fig. 6(b). Since MgO does not form a hydride of Mg under the reaction conditions, the formation energy (absolute value) is much lower than the hydrides of La, Sm, and all the other lanthanide metals. If an actual volcano-type relationship exists for the hydride formation energy, an optimal hydride formation energy similar to the optimal nitride formation energy could exist for optimal NH3 synthesis activity. Since hydride formation energy represents the bond strength between a support metal and a hydrogen atom, there could be an optimal support metal-hydrogen bond strength that correlates with the optimal activity. It can be postulated that a strong support metal-hydrogen bond strength would strongly bind hydrogen to the support metal and would not allow the hydrogen migration, e.g., Er and Tb. In contrast, a weaker support metal-hydrogen bond strength would not even allow a hydride to be formed, e.g., Mg, keeping all hydrogen atoms on the Ru surface. An optimal bond strength between support metal and hydrogen atoms would alleviate the hydrogen inhibition by the reduction of H2 at the oxygen vacancy at the formation of metal hydride where the hydrogen is easily migrated to Ru to participate in the reaction [45,46] and the hydroxyl groups where the hydrogen is diffused over the support surface via the proton exchange [63]. The strength of the metal-hydrogen bond can be qualitatively estimated using the H2-TPD profiles of metal hydrides, which are shown in Fig. 10 . Here, the metal powder is heated under hydrogen at 500 °C for 6 h to form a metal hydride. After removing excess hydrogen, the TPD is performed starting at 100 °C (See Supplementary information). According to the TPD profiles, after the reaction temperature of 400 °C, Er, and Tb bind hydrogen strongly, forming metal hydrides with higher formation energies expected, as depicted in Fig. 6(b). The metal hydrides of Ce and Sm decompose or desorb hydrogen at lower temperatures (400 °C) compared to Er and Tb (800–1000 °C). The Ru catalysts supported on Tb2O3 and Er2O3 exhibit lower activities than those supported on CeO2 and Sm2O3. These results indicate a correlation between the hydrogen bond strength of the support metal and the activity of the supported Ru catalyst, as postulated by the previous discussion. For mixed oxides, either one metal or both metals could be present on the surface under the reaction conditions. Hence, to investigate this relationship for mixed metal oxides, the NH3-TPD appears to be a suitable descriptor compared to the H2-TPD of support metals since determining what metal is on the oxide surface is not trivial under a certain temperature for ternary metal oxides [40]. The ternary metal oxide supports were selected from the materials project website [42] for Ce-based A2B2O7 type mixed oxides since the model is mostly trained with these oxides containing Ce. The selected supports were Ce2Sm2O7, Ce2Y2O7, Ce2Nd2O7, Ce2Dy2O7 and Ce2La2O7. These were synthesized via co-precipitation, and the NH3 synthesis activity was measured for 5 wt% Ru impregnated on these supports. The reaction results of these mixed oxide supports are shown in Fig. 11 . The catalysts Ru/Ce2Sm2O7, Ru/Ce2Dy2O7, and Ru/Ce2Dy2O7 had activities of around 4 to 5 mmol h−1gcat −1 similar to Ru/MgO under the same reaction condition, which is very low compared to other catalysts supported on binary metal oxide supports. Only Ru/Ce2La2O7 and Ru/Ce2Y2O7 catalysts had significant activity, exceeding 10 mmol h−1gcat −1. The NH3-TPD results of these ternary metal oxides (Fig. 12 ) revealed that supports that contributed to low activity similar to MgO, such as Ce2Sm2O7 and Ce2Dy2O7, slightly adsorbed or did not adsorb any measurable amount of NH3 similar to MgO. Hence, it appears that adding other metals has eliminated the acid sites of CeO2, most probably making the oxide surface with only basic sites. The oxide Ce2Nd2O7 has slightly increased its weak and strong acid sites compared to Ce2Sm2O7 and Ce2Dy2O7, resulting in a slight increase in the activity. The NH3-TPD profile of Ce2Y2O7 is similar to Er2O3 and Ho2O3, where the NH3 is desorbing continuously over a wide range of temperatures from 100-800 °C and activity of a similar range of 12–15 mmol h−1gcat −1. La2Ce2O7 was not as strongly acidic as Ce2Y2O7 nor slightly acidic as Ce2Nd2O7 and has a discontinuous NH3-TPD profile with weak and strong acid sites. Ru/La2Ce2O7 had the highest activity out of all the ternary metal oxides considered, exceeding the activity of the parent oxide CeO2-supported catalyst, which had the highest activity among all the other binary metal oxide supports considered so far. Hence, these results indicate that the acid site strength or the strength of the interaction between NH3 and the ternary metal oxides are highly correlated with the activity, and an optimal acidity could exist, similar to the binary metal oxides discussed earlier. The correlation between the NH3-TPD profiles and activity was tested for other binary metal oxide-supported Ru catalysts that were not in the dataset used to train the ML model. These experiments would evaluate the extrapolative capability of the correlations identified so far using SHAP. Since the correlation is shown for binary metal oxides with basic sites, one phase and clear crystal structure synthesized using co-precipitation, which has nanoparticle morphology for Ru by wetness impregnation, the new binary oxides must be selected to match that criterion. Hence, Y2O3 and ZrO2 were selected with the added consideration of transition metal oxide-supported catalysts not being included in the training dataset. Dy2O3 was also selected to investigate the validity of the correlation for lanthanide oxide-supported catalysts that were not included in the dataset. The support metal nitride formation energy per metal mol values for Y2O3, ZrO2, and Dy2O3 values are −385.86, −381.21, and −389.93 kJ mol−1, as shown in Table S1. According to Fig. 6(a), which depicts the correlation, Y2O3, ZrO2, and Dy2O3 should possess strong acidic sites (NH3 desorbing at temperatures > 400 °C), similar to Er2O3 and Ho2O3, with activities similar to Er2O3 and Ho2O3 in the supported Ru catalysts. NH3-TPD results (Fig. 13 ) demonstrate that Y2O3, ZrO2, and Dy2O3 possess strong acidic sites as expected. However, only Dy2O3 had a continuous profile similar to Er2O3 and Ho2O3, most probably due to all of the metal oxides being lanthanide metal oxides. Y2O3 had a discontinuous NH3-TPD profile in which a peak is centered at 400 °C. The portion of the NH3-TPD profile at temperatures greater than 400 °C is bigger in ZrO2 compared to all other oxides, making it the most acidic binary metal oxide considered so far in this study. The activity of all of the catalysts from these supports was not as low as expected (Fig. 14 ). Only Ru/Dy2O3 had the expected lower activity of 15 mmol h−1gcat −1. Ru/Y2O3 activity was higher than all the other catalysts, with an activity of 29 mmol h−1gcat −1, whereas Ru/ZrO2 did not have any measurable activity. These experimental data suggest that the descriptor, the most thermodynamically stable support metal nitride formation energy per metal mol, is insufficient to correlate the acidity of metal oxide support (measured by NH3-TPD) to activity. The descriptor was sufficient enough to describe the activity for supports such as MgO, where there was no desorption profile, and lanthanide metal oxide supports, including Dy2O3, where the desorption profile was continuous and mostly spread through temperatures less than the reaction temperature of 400 °C, where a single value would be enough to describe the profile. Hence, the incompatibility of this descriptor, mainly seen in Y2O3 and ZrO2, could be caused by neglecting the distribution of nitride formation energies of the support metal. The distribution of the formation energy of all the thermodynamically stable and metastable metal nitrides (energy above the hull, less than or equal to 0.2) extracted from the materials project website [42] with GGA/GGA + U/ r2SCAN mixed scheme is plotted in Fig. 15 as the mean and the standard deviation. The metals for this plot are selected to form potential binary metal oxide supports with basic sites, which are necessary to drive the NH3 synthesis reaction that does not reduce to metal under a hydrogen atmosphere. It effectively eliminates stable oxides such as SiO2, GeO2, WO3, MoO3, Ta2O5, Nb2O5, and V2O5 due to the absence of basic sites [64]. The oxides formed by Cu, Zn, Mo, and Sn are Re are eliminated due to the reduction of oxide to bulk metal under an H2 atmosphere with high temperatures [65,66]. The acid strength on the x-axis in Fig. 15 is similar to Fig. 6(a). However, the information on the y-axis for the distribution has added extra information to differentiate between Y2O3 and ZrO2. ZrO2 has a much higher standard deviation of the higher nitride formation energy, indicating a wider distribution of strong acid sites. TiO2 is also in this region, which has been observed to contain a wider distribution of strong acid sites, leading to low activity [39]. The alkaline and alkaline earth metal oxide supports, such as MgO and Cs2O, are clustered in the area of lower nitride formation energy with a lower distribution, where moderate activity can be expected [67]. The exception is BaO, having a low nitride formation energy with a higher distribution, indicating a strong basicity. The vast majority of lanthanide metal oxide supports are clustered in the high nitride formation energy with a low distribution area that contributes to high activity. In each of these clustered regions, the metal oxides for which deviations can be expected from the common behavior in each region are marked in red. These include metals that form different phases of oxides (i.e., Al, Ga, Ti, Zr, Cr) and multiple oxidation states (i.e., Cr, Mn, Pr, Tb) when synthesized with the co-precipitation method [17,68]. The best example of this deviation is Al2O3, where the activity of the supported Ru catalysts varies highly depending on the phase of alumina obtained by higher calcination temperatures (i.e., alpha, theta, gamma) [69]. These Al2O3-supported catalysts are reported to be low-active [23,70,71], as well as high-active [72]. Based on these results, it is apparent that the mean and the standard deviation of the distribution of nitride formation energies per metal mol are sufficient to describe the activity of the binary metal oxide-supported Ru catalysts, given that the support does not form complex phases and possesses basic sites. These descriptors were sufficient to describe the behavior of binary metal oxide supports that were not in the dataset, as evidenced by the behavior of TiO2 and other alkaline earth-supported catalysts. The synergy of lanthanide metals in the high-activity cluster (Fig. 15) in ternary oxide support does not always lead to high activity, as seen in Fig. 11. The combination of La-Ce resulted in high activity compared to their parent oxides. In contrast, the Ce-Sm and Ce-Y combinations resulted in activities way lower than their parent oxides. Hence, these descriptors seem insufficient to describe the complex behavior of ternary metal oxide supports. It would also limit the reintegration of these descriptors to the ML model since a significant amount of the dataset is comprised of ternary metal oxide supports. Further analysis is required to use these descriptors for ternary metal oxides, which is beyond the scope of this study. However, the NH3-TPD profile of either the binary or ternary oxide support can be used to pre-determine whether the supported Ru catalyst has low, moderate, or high activity. Based on the experimental results observed so far, the metal oxide supports can be categorized into three classes based on the NH3-TPD profile. 1) Highly significant peaks that extend to temperatures greater than 400 °C: low activity 2) No significant peaks or insignificant peaks: moderate activity 3) Highly significant peaks mostly limited to temperatures less than 400 °C: high activity. 4 Conclusions The ML model developed from the experimental data mined from the literature is used to investigate the role of the metal oxide support for Ru-based NH3 synthesis catalysts. The domain knowledge-based descriptors for metal oxide were integrated into the model so that interpretable ML models can be used to develop correlations between descriptors and the catalyst performance. The model revealed that Pr2O3 is a significant outlier, and removing this data significantly increased the model's accuracy. The descriptors support metal nitride formation energy and metal hydride formation energy, demonstrated volcano-type relationships with the catalyst activity. The physical existence of these relationships was verified using NH3-TPD and H2-TPD experiments. However, it was observed that these relationships were only valid for lanthanide metal oxide support when NH3-TPD was performed for supports that were not in the dataset. The mean and the standard deviation of the formation energy per metal mol of all thermodynamically stable and meta-stable compounds (energy above the hull, less than or equal to 0.2) were sufficient to describe the behavior of all of the binary metal oxide supports. Combined with the experimental NH3-TPD results, these descriptors could categorize metal oxide supports into three categories. These results also suggest that the metal oxide support should possess a certain amount of acidity to drive the NH3 synthesis reaction, most probably due to the acidity required to alleviate NH3 inhibition. This knowledge gained through the interpretable ML model and catalyst characterization is different from the current idea that the acidity of the metal oxide is detrimental to the reaction. Moreover, it was suggested that the formation of metal hydrides by hydrogen migration could be critical to the behavior of hydrogen on the metal oxide surface. Compared to the current knowledge about this system, it is plausible that the strong metal support interaction would facilitate the migration of hydrogen and NH3 to the support. Hence, an interpretable ML model combined with catalyst characterization was able to gain new insights into the NH3 synthesis reaction. It is expected that tuning the acidity and hydride formation of the metal oxide support would lead to catalyst design with increased NH3 synthesis activity. coredata.dc:description: The role of metal oxide supports is complex in heterogeneous catalysis due to acidity, basicity, and surface defects. Interpretable machine learning models trained on experimental data could lead to new insights about these complexities, which are rarely verified through detailed catalyst characterization. This study explores the role of metal oxide supports for the Ru-based ammonia synthesis catalysts using Shapley additive explanations (SHAP). The support metal nitride formation energy and the support metal hydride formation energy were identified as critical descriptors that could describe the ammonia synthesis activity. These descriptors and the related catalyst characterization by Ammonia-Temperature Programmed Desorption and Hydrogen-Temperature Programmed Desorption suggest new processes that could govern the ammonia synthesis reaction. It is suggested that in addition to basicity, the metal oxide support should possess a certain acidity to alleviate ammonia inhibition and form metal hydrides to alleviate hydrogen inhibition.
